points.title: Grammarly does not notify users before being involved in a merger, sale, or acquisition

topics.description: When you give your data to a company, you need to keep in mind that this company can get acquired by another company, with different policies. What happens in that case?

meta.license-for-this-file: This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License. topics.name: Business Transfers
topics.subtitle: Is your data a business asset?
topics.title: Business Transfers

tosdr.case: may sell your data in merger
tosdr.tldr: Grammarly does not inform users before being involved in a merger, sale, or acquisition. They do, however, notify users via email and post a notice on their site regarding any choices you may have regarding your personal information.

topics.name: User information
topics.subtitle: Transparency and education
topics.title: User information

tosdr.case: no pricing info given before you sign up
tosdr.tldr: You must sign up for Grammarly's service in order to learn what the different pricing packages are. However, pricing packages as of 15 March 2012 are listed in a support document at: http://support.grammarly.com/entries/21138022-current-grammarly-subscription-plans.

topics.name: Guarantee
topics.subtitle: Some services will guarantee you certain features, or explicitly reject any guarantee.
topics.title: Guarantee

tosdr.tldr: Grammarly restricts your use to 100 documents/50,000 words within a 24-hr period and 300 documents/150,000 words per month.

topics.name: Governance
topics.subtitle: Your relationship with the service and the community
topics.title: Governance

tosdr.case: liability limited to fees you paid
tosdr.tldr: Grammarly isn't liable in any event regarding the Site, Services, and/or Software for any amount in the aggregate in excess of fees you have actually paid to Grammarly during the 12 month period immediately before the event that gave rise to such liability.

topics.name: Law and government requests
topics.subtitle: How do services deal with government requests?
topics.title: Law and government requests

tosdr.tldr: Although Grammarly may disclose your personal information in light of a subpoena, or when they believe in good faith that it is necessary to protect their rights or yours, for example, they make no promise to inform users about such a request and/or disclosure.

points.title: Grammarly uses third-party cookies and Google to show ads

topics.description: Cookies are files stored locally in your web browser containing identifiable information.

topics.name: Cookies
topics.subtitle: and related technologies
topics.title: Cookies

tosdr.tldr: Grammarly uses Google Analytics and DoubleClick to track your browsing history and in turn provide targeted advertisements. They do, however, mention that you can opt out of Google Analytics for Display Advertisers and customized Google Display Network ads in the Ads Preferences Manager.
